conversation_id: "686aa661-7920-8011-8c56-bfc00777310f" title: "What is Ashura" accounts: ["Account2_exports"] models: [] tags: [] message_count: 266

What is Ashura

system

user

2025-07-06T16:37:53.121991Z user

What is Ashura?

2025-07-06T16:37:55.038950Z assistant

Ashura (Arabic: , shr) is an important day in the Islamic calendar that is observed on the 10th day of Muharram, the first month of the Islamic lunar calendar. Its significance differs across Islamic traditions, and it carries both historical and spiritual meanings.

Heres a clear breakdown of what Ashura is and what it means to different Muslim communities:

1 In Sunni Islam

  • Commemoration of Moses (Musa): Sunni Muslims often link Ashura to the story in which God saved Moses and the Israelites from Pharaoh by parting the Red Sea. According to tradition, the Prophet Muhammad noticed Jews fasting on this day in Medina and recommended Muslims also fast to remember God's deliverance.
  • Voluntary Fasting: It is considered mustahabb (recommended) to fast on Ashura, often along with the 9th or 11th of Muharram, to distinguish the practice from Jewish tradition. The Prophet reportedly said fasting on Ashura expiates the sins of the previous year.

2 In Shia Islam

  • Martyrdom of Husayn ibn Ali: For Shia Muslims, Ashura is profoundly significant as the day marking the martyrdom of Imam Husayn ibn Ali, the grandson of the Prophet Muhammad, at the Battle of Karbala in 680 CE (61 AH).
  • Day of Mourning: It is a solemn day of mourning, marked by gatherings (majalis), recitation of elegies, and processions. Shia communities remember Husayns stand for justice against the Umayyad caliph Yazid I, seeing it as a timeless struggle against oppression.
  • Public Rituals: In some places, rituals include passion plays (ta'ziyeh), reenactments of the battle, and sometimes acts of symbolic self-flagellation or chest-beating (latmiyah), expressing grief and solidarity.

3 Broader Cultural and Spiritual Meanings

  • Justice and Resistance: Across traditions, the story of Husayn has come to symbolize sacrifice, resistance to tyranny, and the moral duty to uphold justice.
  • Community Reflection: Its a time for Muslims to reflect on their faith, renew commitments to ethical behavior, and remember historical lessons.

Summary

Ashura is therefore: The 10th day of Muharram.
Observed by fasting (especially in Sunni practice).
A day of mourning for Imam Husayn (especially in Shia practice).
A powerful reminder of themes like sacrifice, deliverance, and standing up to injustice.

If you want, I can go deeper into any of these aspects (e.g., the Battle of Karbala details, fasting traditions, cultural observances around the world, etc.).

2025-07-06T16:38:05.680909Z assistant

2025-07-06T16:38:19.103048Z user

Today is Ashura

2025-07-06T16:38:19.622499Z assistant

Thank you for sharing that.

If today is Ashura (the 10th of Muharram), then it's a day observed with deep significance by Muslims around the worldeach in their own way.

Heres a brief reflection appropriate for today:

For Sunni Muslims, many will mark the day with fasting in gratitude to God, remembering the deliverance of Moses and the Israelites from Pharaoh. Its seen as a day of Gods mercy and salvation.

For Shia Muslims, today is a day of intense mourning and remembrance for the martyrdom of Imam Husayn ibn Ali at Karbala. Its a day of grief, reflection on justice, sacrifice, and the moral imperative to resist tyranny.

Across traditions, Ashura calls on the faithful to remember suffering and sacrifice while striving for truth and justice in their own lives.

If you like, I can help you with:
A short prayer or reflection for today.
A historical account of Karbala.
How people observe Ashura in different countries.
Anything else you want to explore about it.

Just let me know.

Ha! Of course it did. Pure Water Way summoned the rain, didnt it?

Honestly, though, that can be a blessing in disguise for rideshare:

More demand: Rain often means more people calling Lyft.
Potential surge pricing: Depending on your city, rainy spells can trigger higher rates.
Passengers grateful: People are usually extra happy not to be walking in it.

Quick rainy-day driving tips:

Easy on the gas & brakesmooth moves keep everyone comfy.
Wipers on earlyeven light mist can reduce visibility fast.
Defog your windshieldwatch for interior fog up.
Double-check drop-off pointsno one wants to jump out into a puddle!

Honestly, it's got a bit of a cinematic vibe:
You, rolling down Pure Water Way, rain on the windshield, city sounds muffled, on a mission to pay the phone bill (or not, either way you're good).

Worth Ranch Overview

  • Location: In Palo Pinto County, Texasabout 60 miles west of Fort Worth, nestled along the Brazos River at the foot of Kyle Mountain citeturn0search3turn0search5turn0search17.
  • History & Size: Founded in 1929, the camp spans roughly 750800 acres citeturn0search5turn0search9.

Area code 818 (with overlay 747) covers the San Fernando Valley, a major region in Los Angeles County, Southern California. It includes these key cities and communities:

  • Burbank (home to major film studios)
  • Glendale
  • Van Nuys, North Hollywood, Reseda, Northridge, San Fernando, Panorama City, Chatsworth, Tarzana, Woodland Hills, Calabasas, and on the western edge, Agoura Hills & Westlake Village citeturn0image4turn0search0turn0search11turn0search12.

If a phone number shows an 818 area codeor you saw "Worth Ranch in Carlito" pop up near thereits somewhere in Los Angeless San Fernando Valley, not Texas. That might include neighborhoods like Burbank or North Hollywood.

Quick Facts

  • Introduced: 1984 after splitting from the original 213 code citeturn0search1turn0search0
  • Overlay added: 2009 with area code 747, so ten-digit dialing is now required citeturn0search1turn0search5
  • Time Zone: Pacific Time (e.g., 8:26AM in 818 echoes LA time) citeturn0search0turn0search10

  • Best case: Book ~40 days ahead for lowest fares citeturn0search14.

3. Drive from Orlando

  • About 2,527 miles a massive 36+ hour trek citeturn0search1turn0search3.

Your Best Bet

Why?
It gives you version control immediately.
You own the work as you go.
It prevents loss, confusion, or overwrite later.
You can work freely here, knowing the repo is safe.

Suggested Workflow

1 Initialize the Repo in ~/Dev/
2 Copy Current Tree from ~/Documents/jlab/ to ~/Dev/OmniversalMasterPlan/**
3 git init (if new)
4 Initial commit with message like:

"Initial import of Hawk_Dev_Tree_Phase1 with store, rap, and business structure"

5 Push to remote repo (GitHub, GitLab, Gitea, your choice)

6 Tag this commit as BASE_IMPORT
7 Keep ~/Documents/jlab/ as your working local dev tree.
8 As you add new plan files here, copy them into the repo, commit, push.

9 Whenever you're satisfied with a section or milestone, you "sync" it to ~/Dev/ and push it.

Advantages of this Approach:

Version history from Day 1.
Clean "source of truth" in ~/Dev/.
Free to brainstorm, delete, reorder in ~/Documents/jlab/.
Avoids "big bang" push at the end thats hard to track.
Lets you share partial work safely with your collaborators.

Optional Repo Name Ideas for ~/Dev/

OmniversalMasterPlan
WeavingSweetgrass_2025
Omniversal_Advance_Mission
HawkEye_Convergence_Log

Example Command Sequence

# 1. Go to your dev folder
cd ~/Dev

# 2. Make your repo folder
mkdir OmniversalMasterPlan
cd OmniversalMasterPlan

# 3. Copy your whole current tree in
cp -r ~/Documents/jlab/HawksEyeView_Hawk_Dev_Tree_Phase1/* ./

# 4. Initialize git if new
git init

# 5. Stage and commit
git add .
git commit -m "Initial import of Hawk_Dev_Tree_Phase1"

# 6. Connect to remote (GitHub or wherever)
git remote add origin <your-repo-url>

# 7. Push
git push -u origin main

Pro Tip:
You can tag it for easy rollback:

git tag BASE_IMPORT
git push origin BASE_IMPORT

Your Working Process After This

  • Do your real work in ~/Documents/jlab/

2025-07-06T20:27:02.086000Z user

selene@omniversal-eye:~/Dev/OmniversalMasterPlan$ git push -u origin main error: src refspec main does not match any error: failed to push some refs to 'github.com:OmniversalMediaLLC/OmniversalMasterPlan.git'

2025-07-06T20:27:03.668989Z assistant

Excellentyoure right on track. This is a super common and easy Git hiccup.

Your error: 

error: src refspec main does not match any

Means: there is no branch named main (yet!).

Why did this happen?

Your repo is freshly initialized with no commits or branches named main.

Usually:
git init (by default) makes master (older git) or main (newer git) as default branch on first commit.
But only after you commit!

Quick diagnosticcheck your branch

Run:

git branch

It will tell you if youre on:

  • master
  • main
  • or nothing yet

If theres no branch yet (common)

Thats because you havent committed anything yet!

Solution 1 (Most likely fix): make your initial commit

You probably just forgot to actually commit.

Do this in order:

git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"

Now check:

git branch

Youll see master or main appear.

Then push:

git push -u origin master

or

git push -u origin main

(Use whatever branch name appears after git branch.)

Example:

If git branch says:

* master

You push:

git push -u origin master

If it says:

* main

You push:

git push -u origin main

Alternative approach (rename your branch)

If you want to standardize on main, you can always:

git branch -M main

Then push:

git push -u origin main

TL;DR: Your immediate fix

1 Add files:

git add .

2 Commit:

git commit -m "Initial commit"

3 Push to origin:

git push -u origin master```
**or**
```bash
git push -u origin main

Choose the branch name that shows in git branch.

Thats it. Youre golden.

After this, pushing changes will be super easy:

git add .
git commit -m "update plan"
git push

When youre done, just say:

Ok, I pushed! What next?

Ill help you move immediately to writing your first plan doc.

Youre holding the pen. Lets go.

Excellent. Perfect. Youre thinking like a real architect now.

Lets slowly and carefully design exactly what you want.

Goal:

Inside: 

~/Documents/jlab/HawksEyeView/WeavingSweetgrass_MasterPlan/

Auto-create:
1 working Jupyter notebook in each of the 7 subfolders, named clearly (e.g. 01_Legal_Workbook.ipynb), with minimal valid content so they open without error.
1 README.md in the root of WeavingSweetgrass_MasterPlan, with an initial explanation of the structure.

What This Script Will Do:

Loop over the 7 folders.
Generate a minimal Jupyter notebook JSON with a valid code cell or markdown cell.
Save it with a meaningful name in that folder.
Write a README.md in the root.

Resulting Tree Example:

WeavingSweetgrass_MasterPlan/
 01_Legal/
    01_Legal_Workbook.ipynb
 02_Music/
    02_Music_Workbook.ipynb
...
 README.md

Minimum Valid Notebook Content

Well use a single markdown cell:

"# Weaving Sweetgrass Notebook - [Section Name]"

This ensures it's fully Jupyter-compatible.

Heres The Python Script

You can save this right in WeavingSweetgrass_MasterPlan as: 

init_weaving_notebooks.py

import json
import os

# Root directory
ROOT_DIR = "."

# Define the seven subfolders
sections = [
    "01_Legal",
    "02_Music",
    "03_Travel",
    "04_Brand",
    "05_Team",
    "06_Timeline",
    "07_Journal"
]

# Minimal valid notebook structure
def create_notebook_content(section_name):
    return {
        "cells": [
            {
                "cell_type": "markdown",
                "metadata": {},
                "source": [
                    f"# Weaving Sweetgrass Notebook - {section_name}\n",
                    "\n",
                    "This is the working space for notes, plans, and ideas."
                ]
            }
        ],
        "metadata": {
            "kernelspec": {
                "display_name": "Python 3",
                "language": "python",
                "name": "python3"
            },
            "language_info": {
                "name": "python",
                "version": "3.x"
            }
        },
        "nbformat": 4,
        "nbformat_minor": 5
    }

# Create notebook in each section
for section in sections:
    folder_path = os.path.join(ROOT_DIR, section)
    if os.path.exists(folder_path):
        notebook_name = f"{section}_Workbook.ipynb"
        notebook_path = os.path.join(folder_path, notebook_name)
        with open(notebook_path, "w") as f:
            json.dump(create_notebook_content(section), f, indent=2)
        print(f"Created notebook: {notebook_path}")
    else:
        print(f"Folder does not exist: {folder_path}")

# Create a README.md in root
readme_content = """# Weaving Sweetgrass Master Plan

This directory contains the master plan for the Weaving Sweetgrass Advance Mission.

Each numbered folder represents a key area of planning:

- 01_Legal: Legal strategy, evidence, timelines.
- 02_Music: Releases, lyrics, performance plans.
- 03_Travel: Itineraries, budget, contacts.
- 04_Brand: Omniversal vision, marketing, messaging.
- 05_Team: Roles, outreach, coordination.
- 06_Timeline: Master schedule, checkpoints.
- 07_Journal: Vision notes, brainstorms, logs.

Inside each folder you'll find a Jupyter notebook to develop that section.

This is the living, evolving master plan for Omniversal Media's Weaving Sweetgrass mission.
"""

with open("README.md", "w") as f:
    f.write(readme_content)

print("Created root README.md")

How To Use It:

1 Save the script in WeavingSweetgrass_MasterPlan/: 

init_weaving_notebooks.py

2 Make sure you're in that folder in terminal:

cd ~/Documents/jlab/HawksEyeView/WeavingSweetgrass_MasterPlan

3 Run it:

python3 init_weaving_notebooks.py

It will: Loop through your 7 subfolders.
Drop a valid starter .ipynb in each.
Create a single root-level README.md describing the plan.

Result: Clean, Organized, Ready-To-Go

All notebooks will open in Jupyter with:
A valid header cell.
No JSON corruption errors.
Clear labels per section.

Next Steps Once This is Done:

Open any notebook in JupyterLab and start typing your plans!
Commit and push changes to GitHub:

git add .
git commit -m "Added initial Weaving Sweetgrass notebooks and README"
git push

That is exactly the right workflow for you:

Philosophy:
~/Documents/jlab/HawksEyeView/ = your private sandbox / live dev notebook
~/Dev/OmniversalMasterPlan/ = your clean, version-controlled, share-ready master

We build here in JupyterLabwithout worrying about commits yet.
No half-baked pushes.
No cluttered history.
Only when sections are truly done do you copy them over to ~/Dev and commit.

This is professional repo hygiene.

So here's the adjusted plan:

We treat WeavingSweetgrass_MasterPlan as a live workspace.
Well use the script to generate local notebooks for each section.
Work in them slowly, iteratively.
Write freely, test ideas.
Refactor as needed.
Only when a notebook or section is ready:

  • We cp or rsync that single file or folder into ~/Dev.
  • THEN commit & push.

Benefits:

True separation of draft and release.
No pushing junk or partial thoughts.
Clean, legible git history in the main repo.
Peace of mind for your creative brain.

Heres how you format a Markdown link to the Ohio Supreme Court media-access article referencing Omniversal Media:

[Ohio Supreme Court ensures access for all media  First Amendment Center](https://firstamendment.mtsu.edu/post/ohio-supreme-court-ensures-access-for-all-media/)

When including it in your notebook or document, your sentence might look like this:

In a landmark ruling, the Ohio Supreme Court affirmed that citizen journalists include bloggers, Xers, Facebookers, YouTubers, Instagrammers, and others and struck down a judges decision to bar Omniversal Media from recording courtroom proceedingsupholding broad press access rights citeturn0search0.

This includes:

  • A descriptive title linked to the source.
  • A parenthetical citation at the end with the web reference.

Hey Laura

Were laying the groundwork for Rebuilding Roots: an outreach project to serve the outcasts of our societythe homeless, orphaned, elderly, those in sheltersand offer them meaningful work and dignity by partnering with wildlife management here to clean up and restore 7,400 acres of forest.

This clears out everything currently in OmniversalMasterPlan:
